# Stablecoin Issuer Licensing and Regulatory Compliance Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Stablecoin Issuer Licensing Framework and VASP Registration Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework for obtaining and maintaining regulatory authorization to issue stablecoins in Mauritius under the Financial Services Act (FSA) and the Virtual Asset and Initial Token Offering Services Act 2021 (VAITOS Act). The policy ensures compliance with all regulatory requirements while establishing clear internal procedures for licensing applications and ongoing regulatory obligations.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
- All proposed stablecoin issuance activities conducted by the organization
- All departments involved in virtual asset services, including technology, legal, compliance, finance, and risk management
- Third-party service providers engaged in activities related to stablecoin issuance
- All jurisdictions where the organization intends to operate under the Mauritius regulatory framework

## 3. Definitions
| Term | Definition |
|------|------------|
| **Stablecoin** | A virtual asset that purports to maintain a stable value relative to a specified reference, or a pool of references, including one or more fiat currencies |
| **VASP** | Virtual Asset Service Provider as defined under Section 2 of the VAITOS Act 2021 |
| **FSC** | Financial Services Commission, Mauritius |
| **Issuer** | An entity that creates stablecoins with the obligation to redeem them on demand |
| **Reserve Assets** | High-quality liquid assets held to fully back outstanding stablecoins |
| **VAITOS Act** | Virtual Asset and Initial Token Offering Services Act 2021 |

## 4. Policy Statement
It is the policy of this organization to:
- Obtain proper licensing as a VASP from the FSC before conducting any stablecoin issuance activities
- Maintain full compliance with all provisions of the FSA and VAITOS Act
- Implement robust governance, risk management, and compliance frameworks
- Ensure 100% backing of issued stablecoins with appropriate reserve assets
- Provide transparent disclosures to users and regulators
- Cooperate fully with regulatory examinations and reporting requirements

## 5. Procedures
### 5.1 Licensing Application Process
#### Phase 1: Pre-Application Preparation (Months 1-3)
- Conduct gap analysis against FSC requirements
- Prepare business plan including:
  - Detailed description of stablecoin model
  - Technology infrastructure assessment
  - Reserve management methodology
  - Redemption procedures
- Draft all required policies (AML/CFT, risk management, cybersecurity, etc.)
- Establish governance structure with Board approval

#### Phase 2: Document Compilation (Month 4)
- Complete FSC VASP application form
- Compile supporting documents:
  - Certificate of incorporation
  - Memorandum and Articles of Association
  - Organizational structure chart
  - Fit and proper declarations for all controllers
  - Audited financial statements (if applicable)
  - Business continuity plan
  - Technology audit report

#### Phase 3: Application Submission and Engagement (Months 5-6)
- Submit complete application package to FSC
- Designate primary contact for regulatory communications
- Prepare for and participate in FSC interviews
- Respond promptly to any FSC queries

#### Phase 4: Post-Submission Requirements
- Implement any conditional requirements specified by FSC
- Prepare for on-site inspection (if required)
- Finalize operational readiness for license commencement

### 5.2 Ongoing Compliance Procedures
- Monthly reserve asset reporting to Compliance Department
- Quarterly compliance certifications to Board Risk Committee
- Semi-annual internal audits of VASP operations
- Annual license renewal preparation starting 3 months before expiry

## 6. Compliance Requirements
### 6.1 Capital Requirements
- Maintain minimum capital as specified by FSC (minimum MUR 500,000 for VASP)
- Hold reserve assets equal to 100% of outstanding stablecoins
- Ensure reserve assets are held in segregated accounts with regulated custodians

### 6.2 Governance Requirements
- Appoint at least two resident directors in Mauritius
- Establish Board Risk Committee with quarterly meetings
- Designate Compliance Officer with direct reporting line to Board
- Implement three lines of defense model

### 6.3 Operational Requirements
- Maintain offices in Mauritius with adequate staffing
- Implement FSC-approved technology systems
- Establish 24/7 redemption mechanism for stablecoins
- Maintain comprehensive transaction records for 7 years

### 6.4 Reporting Requirements

|-------------|-----------|----------|------------------------|
| Financial Statements | Annual | 4 months after year-end | Finance |
| AML/CFT Report | Quarterly | 15 days after quarter-end | Compliance |
| Reserve Asset Report | Monthly | 5 business days after month-end | Treasury |
| Incident Reports | Immediate | Within 24 hours of incident | Operations |
| Significant Changes | Prior notice | 30 days before implementation | Legal |

### 6.5 Risk Management Requirements
- Conduct quarterly risk assessments
- Maintain cybersecurity insurance (minimum MUR 10 million)
- Implement real-time transaction monitoring
- Conduct annual penetration testing
- Establish disaster recovery site with 4-hour recovery time objective

## 7. Review and Update Schedule

# Stablecoin Reserve Management and Asset Backing Policy

## 1. Policy Title  
Stablecoin Reserve Management and Asset Backing Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope  
### Purpose  
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework for the management, composition, custody, and verification of reserves backing all issued stablecoins. The primary objectives are to:  
- Ensure 1:1 backing of all stablecoins in circulation with high-quality liquid assets.  
- Mitigate credit, market, and liquidity risks associated with reserve holdings.  
- Provide transparency and assurance to stakeholders, including regulators, users, and auditors.  
- Ensure compliance with applicable regulatory requirements for stablecoin issuers.

### Scope  
This policy applies to:  
- All stablecoins issued by [Organization Name].  
- All departments and personnel involved in the management, investment, custody, or reporting of reserve assets.  
- Any third-party service providers engaged for custody, asset management, or audit functions.

## 3. Definitions  
- **Stablecoin:** A digital asset issued by [Organization Name] designed to maintain a stable value relative to a specified fiat currency (e.g., USD).  
- **Reserve Assets:** The portfolio of assets held to fully back the outstanding supply of stablecoins.  
- **High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA):** Assets that are low-risk, easily and quickly convertible to cash with minimal loss of value, as defined in Section 5.1.  
- **Custodian:** A regulated, independent financial institution responsible for safeguarding reserve assets.  
- **Cover Ratio:** The ratio of the market value of reserve assets to the total face value of stablecoins in circulation.  
- **Independent Auditor:** A qualified third-party firm engaged to perform attestation on reserve holdings and compliance with this policy.

## 4. Policy Statement  
[Organization Name] will maintain at all times a 1:1 cover ratio between the market value of its reserve assets and the total face value of stablecoins in circulation. Reserve assets shall consist exclusively of High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA) held with regulated custodians. The composition, custody, and verification of reserves shall be governed by the procedures outlined in this document to ensure safety, liquidity, and transparency.

## 5. Procedures  
### 5.1 Asset Composition Rules  
Reserve assets must be held in the following HQLA categories:  
- **Cash and Cash Equivalents:**  
  - Deposits held at regulated U.S. banks (FDIC-insured up to applicable limits).  
  - U.S. Treasury bills with remaining maturity of 3 months or less.  
- **Short-Term Government Securities:**  
  - Direct obligations of the U.S. Treasury with remaining maturity of 12 months or less.  
- **Overnight Repurchase Agreements:**  
  - Secured by U.S. Treasury collateral and transacted through approved counterparties.  

**Prohibited Assets:** Cryptocurrencies, corporate bonds, equities, derivatives, illiquid securities, or any assets with significant credit or market risk are strictly prohibited.

### 5.2 Custody Arrangements  
- All reserve assets must be held with one or more custodians that are:  
  - Regulated as a trust company, bank, or similar financial institution in a reputable jurisdiction.  
  - Independent from [Organization Name]’s operational management.  
- Custody agreements must require:  
  - Segregation of [Organization Name]’s assets from custodian assets and other clients.  
  - Daily reporting of asset balances and transactions.  
  - No encumbrance, lien, or rehypothecation of assets without explicit prior written authorization.

### 5.3 Daily Management and Reporting  
- The Treasury Department will calculate the total stablecoins in circulation at the close of each business day.  
- The market value of reserve assets will be marked-to-market daily.  
- A daily cover ratio report will be generated and reviewed by the Chief Financial Officer (CFO). Any deviation below 100% will trigger immediate remedial action under the Treasury Department’s contingency procedures.

## 6. Compliance Requirements  
### 6.1 Independent Audit  
- An independent, third-party audit firm will be engaged to perform:  
  - **Monthly Attestation:** A monthly examination verifying that reserve assets meet or exceed the outstanding stablecoin liabilities as of month-end.  
  - **Annual Comprehensive Audit:** An annual audit of reserve holdings, custody arrangements, and internal controls, resulting in an opinion report published publicly.  
- Audit reports will be published on [Organization Name]’s website within 30 days of completion.

### 6.2 Public Disclosure  
- A publicly accessible real-time dashboard will display:  
  - Total stablecoins in circulation.  
  - Total value of reserve assets.  
  - Current cover ratio.  
  - Breakdown of reserve asset composition by category.  
- A monthly reserve report, signed by the CFO, will be published summarizing month-end positions and audit status.

### 6.3 Internal Controls and Oversight  
- The Audit Committee of the Board of Directors will oversee compliance with this policy.  
- Internal audits will be conducted quarterly to review adherence to procedures and controls.  
- All personnel with access to reserve management must complete relevant training on this policy annually.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule  
This policy will be reviewed and updated:  
- **Annually** by the Compliance and Treasury departments.  
- **Immediately** following any material change in applicable regulations.  
- All revisions require approval by the Chief Compliance Officer and the Audit Committee.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements  
This policy is designed to align with current and emerging regulatory frameworks for stablecoin issuers, including but not limited to:  
- Principles outlined in the **President’s Working Group Report on Stablecoins** (November 2021).  
- Proposed **Stablecoin Trust Act** and similar legislative initiatives requiring 1:1 backing with HQLA.  
- **New York State Department of Financial Services (NYDFS) Part 114 Stablecoin Issuance Guidelines**.  
- Relevant **Bank Secrecy Act (BSA)/Anti-Money Laundering (AML)** requirements for reserve transparency.  
- **SEC** guidance on the treatment of digital assets and securities held in reserves.

---

*Approved By: [Name, Title]*  
*Version: 1.0*
```

# AML/CFT Compliance Policy for Virtual Asset Service Provider (VASP) Operations

## 1. Policy Title
**Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT) Policy for Stablecoin and Virtual Asset Services**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to detect, prevent, and report money laundering (ML), terrorist financing (TF), and other illicit financial activities in accordance with the Financial Intelligence and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2002. It is designed specifically for the company’s operations as a Virtual Asset Service Provider (VASP) dealing in stablecoins and other virtual assets.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
- All employees, contractors, directors, and officers of the company
- All products and services involving the issuance, exchange, transfer, custody, or administration of stablecoins and other virtual assets
- All customer relationships and transactions, regardless of size or jurisdiction
- All business units, subsidiaries, and affiliated entities operating under the company’s license

## 3. Definitions
- **AML/CFT:** Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism
- **VASP:** Virtual Asset Service Provider – A business that conducts one or more of the following activities: exchange between virtual assets and fiat currencies, exchange between virtual assets, transfer of virtual assets, safekeeping/administering virtual assets, and participation in financial services related to issuer offer/sale.
- **Stablecoin:** A type of virtual asset designed to maintain a stable value relative to a specified asset or pool of assets.
- **CDD:** Customer Due Diligence – The process of identifying and verifying customer identity and assessing risk.
- **EDD:** Enhanced Due Diligence – Additional measures for higher-risk customers.
- **SAR:** Suspicious Activity Report – A report filed with the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) regarding suspicious transactions.
- **Beneficial Owner:** The natural person(s) who ultimately owns or controls a customer or the natural person on whose behalf a transaction is conducted.
- **PEP:** Politically Exposed Person – An individual entrusted with prominent public functions.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Company Name] is committed to full compliance with the Financial Intelligence and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2002 and all associated regulations. We adopt a risk-based approach (RBA) to AML/CFT, ensuring that our resources are allocated effectively to mitigate the highest risks associated with our stablecoin and virtual asset operations. We prohibit all business relationships and transactions involving illicit activities and will cooperate fully with competent authorities.

## 5. Procedures

### A. Risk-Based Approach (RBA)
1. **Risk Assessment:** Conduct a periodic (at least annual) enterprise-wide ML/TF risk assessment considering:
   - Customer types (e.g., individuals, MSBs, corporates)
   - Geography (country/jurisdiction risks)
   - Products and services (e.g., private wallet transfers, fiat on/off ramps)
   - Delivery channels (e.g., web platform, API)
   - Transaction size, volume, and patterns

2. **Risk Mitigation:** Implement controls proportionate to the identified risk levels (Low, Medium, High).

### B. Customer Due Diligence (CDD)
1. **Standard CDD:** Applied to all customers at onboarding, including:
   - Identification and verification of identity using reliable, independent source documents or data.
   - Identification of beneficial owners (for legal persons/arrangements).
   - Understanding the purpose and intended nature of the business relationship.
   - Ongoing monitoring of transactions to ensure consistency with the customer's profile.

2. **Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD):** Mandatory for high-risk categories, including:
   - PEPs, their family members, and close associates.
   - Customers from high-risk jurisdictions.
   - Customers involved in complex, unusually large, or unusual pattern transactions.
   - Private wallet transactions exceeding defined thresholds.
   - EDD measures include obtaining senior management approval, establishing source of wealth/funds, and conducting increased ongoing monitoring.

3. **Simplified Due Diligence:** May be applied only where the ML/TF risk is demonstrably low, in strict accordance with the Act.

4. **Timing of Verification:** CDD must be completed before establishing a business relationship or conducting an occasional transaction. In specific, non-risk scenarios, verification may be completed *during* establishment, provided ML/TF risks are effectively managed.

### C. Transaction Monitoring and Reporting
1. **Automated Monitoring System:** Maintain a system to monitor customer transactions for unusual or suspicious patterns. Parameters will be calibrated based on the company’s risk assessment.
2. **Suspicious Activity Reporting (SAR):** Any employee who detects a suspicious transaction must immediately report it to the Compliance Officer. The Compliance Officer will investigate and, if warranted, file a SAR with the FIU without delay and without tipping off the customer.
3. **Record Keeping:** Maintain all CDD information, transaction records, and SAR documentation for a minimum period of seven (7) years from the date of transaction or end of business relationship, as required by law.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
- **Designated Compliance Officer:** A qualified Compliance Officer (MLRO) is appointed with full responsibility, authority, and independence to implement and oversee the AML/CFT program.
- **Employee Training:** All relevant personnel must undergo annual AML/CFT training, covering obligations under this policy, red flag indicators, and SAR procedures.
- **Independent Audit:** The AML/CFT program will be subject to an independent internal or external audit at least every two years.
- **Sanctions Screening:** All customers (natural and legal persons) must be screened against relevant national and international sanctions lists (e.g., UN, OFAC) at onboarding and on an ongoing basis.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
- **Annually,** as part of the company’s routine risk assessment cycle.
- **Immediately,** following any material changes in regulations, the company’s business model, products, or in response to significant ML/TF incidents.
- All updates require approval by the Board of Directors or designated committee.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is formulated to ensure compliance with, but not limited to, the following:
- **Primary Law:** The Financial Intelligence and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2002 (and any subsequent amendments).
- **Guidance:** Any directives, guidelines, or circulars issued by the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) or other competent regulatory authority pertaining to VASPs and virtual assets.
- **International Standards:** The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) Recommendations, particularly Recommendation 15 and its Interpretive Note on Virtual Assets.

# Stablecoin Consumer Protection and Disclosure Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Stablecoin Holder Consumer Protection, Disclosure, and Redemption Rights Policy

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive consumer protection framework for all holders of stablecoins issued or managed by [Organization Name]. Its purpose is to ensure fair treatment, transparency, and the safeguarding of holder rights through clear disclosures, reliable redemption mechanisms, and accessible complaint resolution procedures.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
*   All stablecoin products issued, managed, or serviced by [Organization Name].
*   All employees, contractors, agents, and partners involved in the issuance, management, marketing, or support of these stablecoins.
*   All interactions with current and prospective stablecoin holders.

## 3. Definitions
*   **Stablecoin:** A digital asset designed to maintain a stable value relative to a specified reference asset or basket of assets (e.g., the U.S. Dollar).
*   **Holder:** Any individual or entity that legally owns stablecoins issued by [Organization Name].
*   **Redemption:** The process by which a holder exchanges stablecoins for the underlying reference asset(s) or its cash equivalent, as defined in the specific stablecoin terms.
*   **Reserves:** The assets held by [Organization Name] to back the outstanding stablecoins in circulation.
*   **Material Information:** Any information a reasonable holder would consider important in making a decision to acquire, hold, or redeem stablecoins, including risks, fees, and reserve composition.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Organization Name] is committed to the highest standards of consumer protection. We will operate with transparency, integrity, and fairness in all dealings with stablecoin holders. This commitment is fulfilled through:
*   **Clear and Accessible Disclosures:** Providing all material information in a clear, conspicuous, and timely manner.
*   **Robust Redemption Rights:** Maintaining a reliable and clearly defined process for holders to redeem stablecoins.
*   **Effective Complaint Resolution:** Operating a fair, accessible, and efficient process for handling holder complaints and disputes.
*   **Data Protection:** Safeguarding holder personal and transactional data in accordance with applicable data protection laws and best practices.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1. Disclosure Requirements
1.  **Pre-Transaction Disclosures:** Prior to any acquisition, the following must be clearly disclosed:
    *   The terms and conditions governing the stablecoin.

## 1. Policy Title
Cybersecurity and Operational Resilience Policy for Stablecoin Infrastructure

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive cybersecurity and operational resilience framework to protect stablecoin infrastructure, ensure the integrity of digital asset operations, and comply with regulatory requirements for Virtual Asset Service Providers (VASPs) as outlined by the Financial Services Commission (FSC) and other relevant authorities.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to:
- All employees, contractors, and third-party service providers involved in stablecoin operations
- All technological systems, networks, and data supporting stablecoin issuance, redemption, transfer, and custody
- All digital asset storage solutions, including hot and cold wallets
- All incident response activities related to cybersecurity events

## 3. Definitions
- **Cold Storage:** A method of storing digital assets offline, disconnected from the internet, to prevent unauthorized access.
- **Hot Wallet:** A digital wallet connected to the internet, used for frequent transactions.
- **Virtual Asset Service Provider (VASP):** Any entity that provides services related to virtual assets, including exchange, transfer, custody, and issuance.
- **Operational Resilience:** The ability to continue operating and delivering critical services through disruptive events.
- **Incident Response Plan (IRP):** A documented set of procedures for detecting, responding to, and recovering from cybersecurity incidents.
- **FSC Guidelines:** The cybersecurity and operational standards issued by the Financial Services Commission for regulated VASPs.

[Organization Name] is committed to maintaining the highest standards of cybersecurity and operational resilience for its stablecoin infrastructure. This policy mandates the implementation of a risk-based cybersecurity framework that protects customer assets, ensures service availability, and complies with all applicable regulatory requirements. All personnel are required to adhere to the procedures outlined herein.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Cybersecurity Framework
A risk-based cybersecurity program shall be implemented, aligned with the FSC guidelines and industry standards (e.g., NIST Cybersecurity Framework). This includes:
- **Risk Assessment:** Conduct annual and ad-hoc risk assessments of all stablecoin systems and processes.
- **Access Controls:** Implement strict principle of least privilege (PoLP) and multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all system access.
- **Network Security:** Deploy firewalls, intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS), and network segmentation.
- **Encryption:** Encrypt all sensitive data at rest and in transit.
- **Vulnerability Management:** Perform regular vulnerability scans and penetration testing.

### 5.2 Digital Asset Storage Policy
#### 5.2.1 Cold Storage
- The majority of reserve assets backing stablecoins shall be held in cold storage.
- Cold storage private keys shall be generated and stored in a physically secure, access-controlled environment (e.g., safe deposit boxes, dedicated vaults).
- Access to cold storage requires dual control (multi-signature) and a minimum of two authorized personnel.
- A detailed log of all cold storage access, deposits, and withdrawals shall be maintained.

#### 5.2.2 Hot Wallet Operations
- Hot wallets shall be used only for operational liquidity needs, with strictly defined maximum balance limits.
- Automated systems shall regularly sweep excess funds from hot wallets to cold storage.
- Hot wallets shall be hosted on dedicated, hardened servers with strict access logs.

### 5.3 Incident Response Plan (IRP)
A formal IRP shall be maintained and tested semi-annually. Key components include:
- **Incident Classification:** A tiered system (e.g., Tier 1-Critical to Tier 3-Minor) for categorizing events.
- **Response Team:** A designated Cybersecurity Incident Response Team (CIRT) with defined roles.
- **Communication Protocol:** Procedures for internal escalation, regulatory reporting (per FSC mandates), and customer notification.
- **Containment & Eradication:** Steps to isolate affected systems and remove threats.
- **Recovery & Restoration:** Processes to restore normal operations from clean backups.
- **Post-Incident Review:** Mandatory analysis to identify root causes and implement corrective actions.

### 5.4 Operational Resilience
- **Business Continuity & Disaster Recovery (BC/DR):** Maintain and test BC/DR plans to ensure continuity of critical stablecoin services.
- **Third-Party Risk Management:** Conduct due diligence on all third-party vendors with access to systems or data.
- **Change Management:** All changes to production systems must follow a formal approval process.

- All sections of this policy are mandatory.
- The Chief Technology Officer (CTO) or designated Information Security Officer is responsible for enforcement.
- Non-compliance may result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination.
- Annual certification of compliance with this policy is required from all relevant department heads.
- Evidence of compliance (logs, reports, test results) must be maintained for regulatory examination.

This policy establishes a formal governance and risk management framework for all stablecoin-related activities conducted by [Organization Name]. *   **Stablecoin:** A digital asset designed to maintain a stable value relative to a specified asset or pool of assets (e.g., fiat currency).
*   **Three Lines of Defense Model:** A structured framework for effective risk management and control:
    *   **First Line:** Business and operational units that own and manage risk.
    *   **Second Line:** Independent risk oversight functions (e.g., Risk Management, Compliance).
    *   **Third Line:** Internal Audit providing independent assurance.

### 5.1 Governance Structure
*   **Board of Directors:** Holds ultimate responsibility for stablecoin governance, approves the Risk Appetite Statement, and oversees the effectiveness of the risk management framework.

The SGC meets quarterly to review risks, control effectiveness, regulatory developments, and reserve attestations.
*   **First Line Management:** Business unit leaders (e.g., Head of Stablecoin Operations) are responsible for day-to-day risk management within their units, implementing controls, and executing processes in line with policy.

### 5.2 The Three Lines of Defense
#### **First Line of Defense – Business & Operations**
*   **Ownership:** Product, technology, and operations teams that design, manage, and execute stablecoin activities.
*   **Responsibilities:** Identify, assess, and manage risks inherent in their processes. Implement and maintain internal controls. Ensure daily operations align with policy and procedure.

## 3. Definitions  
- **Stablecoin:** A digital asset issued by [Organization Name] designed to maintain a stable value relative to a specified fiat currency (e.g., USD).

- **Cover Ratio:** The ratio of the market value of reserve assets to the total face value of stablecoins in circulation.  
- **Independent Auditor:** A qualified third-party firm engaged to perform attestation on reserve holdings and compliance with this policy.

[Organization Name] will maintain at all times a 1:1 cover ratio between the market value of its reserve assets and the total face value of stablecoins in circulation. Reserve assets shall consist exclusively of High-Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA) held with regulated custodians. The composition, custody, and verification of reserves shall be governed by the procedures outlined in this document to ensure safety, liquidity, and transparency.

## 5. Procedures  
### 5.1 Asset Composition Rules

- **Cash and Cash Equivalents:**  
  - Deposits held at regulated U.S. banks (FDIC-insured up to applicable limits).  
  - U.S. Treasury bills with remaining maturity of 3 months or less.  
- **Short-Term Government Securities:**  
  - Direct obligations of the U.S. Treasury with remaining maturity of 12 months or less.  
- **Overnight Repurchase Agreements:**  
  - Secured by U.S. Treasury collateral and transacted through approved counterparties.

# AML/CFT Compliance Policy for Virtual Asset Service Provider (VASP) Operations

## 1. Policy Title
**Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT) Policy for Stablecoin and Virtual Asset Services**

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### Purpose
This policy establishes a comprehensive framework to detect, prevent, and report money laundering (ML), terrorist financing (TF), and other illicit financial activities in accordance with the Financial Intelligence and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2002. It is designed specifically for the company’s operations as a Virtual Asset Service Provider (VASP) dealing in stablecoins and other virtual assets.

### Scope
This policy applies to:
- All employees, contractors, directors, and officers of the company
- All products and services involving the issuance, exchange, transfer, custody, or administration of stablecoins and other virtual assets
- All customer relationships and transactions, regardless of size or jurisdiction
- All business units, subsidiaries, and affiliated entities operating under the company’s license

## 3. Definitions
- **AML/CFT:** Anti-Money Laundering and Countering the Financing of Terrorism
- **VASP:** Virtual Asset Service Provider – A business that conducts one or more of the following activities: exchange between virtual assets and fiat currencies, exchange between virtual assets, transfer of virtual assets, safekeeping/administering virtual assets, and participation in financial services related to issuer offer/sale.
- **Stablecoin:** A type of virtual asset designed to maintain a stable value relative to a specified asset or pool of assets.
- **CDD:** Customer Due Diligence – The process of identifying and verifying customer identity and assessing risk.
- **EDD:** Enhanced Due Diligence – Additional measures for higher-risk customers.
- **SAR:** Suspicious Activity Report – A report filed with the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) regarding suspicious transactions.
- **Beneficial Owner:** The natural person(s) who ultimately owns or controls a customer or the natural person on whose behalf a transaction is conducted.
- **PEP:** Politically Exposed Person – An individual entrusted with prominent public functions.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Company Name] is committed to full compliance with the Financial Intelligence and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2002 and all associated regulations. We adopt a risk-based approach (RBA) to AML/CFT, ensuring that our resources are allocated effectively to mitigate the highest risks associated with our stablecoin and virtual asset operations. We prohibit all business relationships and transactions involving illicit activities and will cooperate fully with competent authorities.

## 5. Procedures

### A. Risk-Based Approach (RBA)
1. **Risk Assessment:** Conduct a periodic (at least annual) enterprise-wide ML/TF risk assessment considering:
   - Customer types (e.g., individuals, MSBs, corporates)
   - Geography (country/jurisdiction risks)
   - Products and services (e.g., private wallet transfers, fiat on/off ramps)
   - Delivery channels (e.g., web platform, API)
   - Transaction size, volume, and patterns

2. **Risk Mitigation:** Implement controls proportionate to the identified risk levels (Low, Medium, High).

### B. Customer Due Diligence (CDD)
1. **Standard CDD:** Applied to all customers at onboarding, including:
   - Identification and verification of identity using reliable, independent source documents or data.
   - Identification of beneficial owners (for legal persons/arrangements).
   - Understanding the purpose and intended nature of the business relationship.
   - Ongoing monitoring of transactions to ensure consistency with the customer's profile.

2. **Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD):** Mandatory for high-risk categories, including:
   - PEPs, their family members, and close associates.
   - Customers from high-risk jurisdictions.
   - Customers involved in complex, unusually large, or unusual pattern transactions.
   - Private wallet transactions exceeding defined thresholds.
   - EDD measures include obtaining senior management approval, establishing source of wealth/funds, and conducting increased ongoing monitoring.

3. **Simplified Due Diligence:** May be applied only where the ML/TF risk is demonstrably low, in strict accordance with the Act.

4. **Timing of Verification:** CDD must be completed before establishing a business relationship or conducting an occasional transaction. In specific, non-risk scenarios, verification may be completed *during* establishment, provided ML/TF risks are effectively managed.

### C. Transaction Monitoring and Reporting
1. **Automated Monitoring System:** Maintain a system to monitor customer transactions for unusual or suspicious patterns. Parameters will be calibrated based on the company’s risk assessment.
2. **Suspicious Activity Reporting (SAR):** Any employee who detects a suspicious transaction must immediately report it to the Compliance Officer. The Compliance Officer will investigate and, if warranted, file a SAR with the FIU without delay and without tipping off the customer.
3. **Record Keeping:** Maintain all CDD information, transaction records, and SAR documentation for a minimum period of seven (7) years from the date of transaction or end of business relationship, as required by law.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
- **Designated Compliance Officer:** A qualified Compliance Officer (MLRO) is appointed with full responsibility, authority, and independence to implement and oversee the AML/CFT program.
- **Employee Training:** All relevant personnel must undergo annual AML/CFT training, covering obligations under this policy, red flag indicators, and SAR procedures.
- **Independent Audit:** The AML/CFT program will be subject to an independent internal or external audit at least every two years.
- **Sanctions Screening:** All customers (natural and legal persons) must be screened against relevant national and international sanctions lists (e.g., UN, OFAC) at onboarding and on an ongoing basis.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
- **Annually,** as part of the company’s routine risk assessment cycle.
- **Immediately,** following any material changes in regulations, the company’s business model, products, or in response to significant ML/TF incidents.
- All updates require approval by the Board of Directors or designated committee.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements

- **Primary Law:** The Financial Intelligence and Anti-Money Laundering Act 2002 (and any subsequent amendments).
- **Guidance:** Any directives, guidelines, or circulars issued by the Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) or other competent regulatory authority pertaining to VASPs and virtual assets.
- **International Standards:** The Financial Action Task Force (FATF) Recommendations, particularly Recommendation 15 and its Interpretive Note on Virtual Assets.

# Regulatory Reporting and Communication Policy

## 1. Policy Title
Regulatory Reporting and Communication Policy for the Financial Services Commission (FSC)

## 2. Purpose and Scope
### 2.1 Purpose
This policy establishes a formal framework to ensure timely, accurate, and complete reporting to the Financial Services Commission (FSC) in compliance with all applicable regulatory obligations. It aims to standardize procedures, assign clear responsibilities, and create a single source of truth for all regulatory communications.

### 2.2 Scope
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, subsidiaries, and business units of [Organization Name] that are involved in the collection, preparation, review, approval, or submission of information to the FSC. It covers all report types, including but not limited to financial, operational, risk, compliance, and incident reports.

## 3. Definitions
*   **FSC:** The Financial Services Commission, the primary regulatory body governing our operations.
*   **Regulatory Reporting Calendar:** The master schedule detailing all periodic and ad-hoc reporting obligations to the FSC, including deadlines, responsible parties, and report descriptions.
*   **Designated Reporting Officer (DRO):** The individual ultimately responsible for the approval and submission of reports to the FSC. This is typically the Chief Compliance Officer or their delegate.
*   **Report Owner:** The department head or manager responsible for the accuracy and timely preparation of a specific report's data and content (e.g., Head of Finance for financial returns).
*   **Material Incident:** Any event that meets the FSC's criteria for mandatory reporting, typically including significant operational disruptions, data breaches, fraud, regulatory breaches, or any event that could significantly impact financial soundness, reputation, or customer interests.

## 4. Policy Statement
[Organization Name] is committed to maintaining the highest standards of regulatory compliance and transparency. It is the policy of this organization to:
*   Proactively identify and fulfill all reporting obligations to the FSC.
*   Ensure all submitted information is accurate, complete, and not misleading.
*   Establish and maintain clear accountability for every reporting requirement.
*   Communicate with the FSC in a professional, consistent, and coordinated manner.
*   Document and retain all submissions and related correspondence.
*   Escalate and report material incidents to the FSC within mandated timeframes.

## 5. Procedures

### 5.1 Regulatory Reporting Calendar
1.  The Compliance Department will create and maintain a master **Regulatory Reporting Calendar**, approved by the DRO.
2.  The Calendar will list every mandated report, its due date, frequency, the FSC reference (form/rule number), the Report Owner, and the data sources.
3.  The Calendar will be distributed quarterly to all Report Owners and senior management and published on the company's intranet.
4.  The Compliance Department will monitor regulatory updates and amend the Calendar within 5 business days of any new requirement being published.

### 5.2 Standard Reporting Workflow
For all periodic reports (e.g., quarterly financials, annual compliance declarations):
1.  **Data Collection & Drafting:** The Report Owner initiates data collection and draft preparation according to the Calendar timeline, allowing for a minimum 10-business-day review window before the submission deadline.
2.  **Internal Review:** The draft report is reviewed sequentially by:
    *   The Report Owner (for accuracy),
    *   The Risk Department (for risk implications),
    *   The Legal Department (for legal sufficiency),
    *   The DRO (for final compliance approval).
3.  **Approval & Submission:** The DRO provides final approval. The Compliance Department submits the report via the FSC's designated portal or method, retaining a dated confirmation receipt.
4.  **Filing:** A complete submission package, including the final report, approval trail, and submission receipt, is archived in the centralized Regulatory Records repository.

### 5.3 Incident Reporting Procedure
1.  **Identification & Immediate Action:** Any employee identifying a *Material Incident* must immediately notify their manager and the Compliance Department.
2.  **Preliminary Assessment:** The Compliance Department, in consultation with Legal and relevant business units, will assess the incident against FSC criteria within [e.g., 2 hours] to confirm reportability.
3.  **Initial Notification:** If reportable, the DRO will ensure an initial notification is made to the FSC within the regulatory mandated timeframe (e.g., 24/48/72 hours), containing all known material facts.
4.  **Follow-Up Report:** A detailed follow-up report, outlining root cause, impact assessment, and remedial actions, will be prepared by the Report Owner and submitted per the FSC's instructions, following the Standard Reporting Workflow (Section 5.2).

### 5.4 Ad-hoc and Query Management
All formal queries, information requests, or surveys from the FSC must be directed immediately to the Compliance Department. The DRO will coordinate the response, utilizing the review and approval steps outlined in Section 5.2.

## 6. Compliance Requirements
*   **Mandatory Training:** All Report Owners and staff in compliance, finance, risk, and legal functions must complete annual training on this policy and FSC reporting requirements.
*   **Record Retention:** All records pertaining to regulatory reports, including drafts, review notes, approval emails, and submission confirmations, must be retained for a minimum of [e.g., 7] years, as per FSC record-keeping rules.
*   **Non-Compliance:** Failure to adhere to this policy, including missed deadlines or submission of inaccurate information, will be treated as a serious compliance breach and may result in disciplinary action. All such instances must be reported to the DRO and may be subject to voluntary disclosure to the FSC.

## 7. Review and Update Schedule
This policy shall be reviewed and updated:
*   **Annually** by the Compliance Department.
*   **Immediately** following any major change in FSC regulations or organizational structure.
*   All revisions require approval by the DRO and the Executive Committee.

## 8. References to Regulatory Requirements
This policy is designed to meet the reporting and transparency obligations under the following (example references - to be tailored):
*   FSC Act [Year], Section XX: Duty to Provide Information.
*   FSC Prudential Standards [Code], Chapter YY: Reporting Requirements.
*   FSC Conduct of Business Rules, Part ZZ: Incident Reporting.
*   FSC Guidance Note GN/202X/XX on Regulatory Reporting.
